articles.title: James Webb catches an exoplanet losing its atmosphere in real time
articles.summary: Astronomers have captured the most dramatic view yet of a planet losing its atmosphere, watching the ultra-hot gas giant WASP-121b for an entire orbit with the James Webb Space Telescope. Instead of a single stream of escaping gas, the planet is wrapped in two colossal helium tails—one trailing behind like a comet, the other stretching ahead toward its star.
articles.content:
Astronomers from the University of Geneva (UNIGE), the National Centre of Competence in Research PlanetS, and the Trottier Institute for Research on Exoplanets (IREx) at the University of Montreal (UdeM) have made a major breakthrough using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST). For the first time, researchers have followed gas escaping from an exoplanet's atmosphere continuously over a full orbit around its star.

The observations revealed an unexpected and dramatic result. The gas giant WASP-121b is surrounded by not one, but two enormous streams of helium that stretch across more than half of its orbit. When combined with advanced computer models developed at UNIGE, the data offer the most detailed look yet at atmospheric escape, a powerful process that can reshape a planet over long periods of time. The findings are published in Nature Communications.

An Ultra Hot Jupiter Under Extreme Conditions

WASP-121b belongs to a class of planets known as ultra hot Jupiters. These massive gas giants orbit extremely close to their stars, and WASP-121b completes a full revolution in just 30 hours. Because of its proximity, intense radiation from the star heats the planet's atmosphere to temperatures of several thousand degrees.

At such extreme heat, lightweight elements like hydrogen and helium can break free and drift into space. Over millions of years, this steady loss of atmospheric material may significantly change the planet's size, composition, and long term evolution.

Why Continuous Observation Matters

Until now, astronomers could only study atmospheric escape during short planetary transits -- the brief moments when a planet passes in front of its star from Earth's perspective. These snapshots lasted only a few hours and provided limited information.

Without uninterrupted monitoring, scientists could not determine how far the escaping gas extended or how its structure changed over time.

A Full Orbit Tracked by James Webb

Using the Near-Infrared Spectrograph (NIRISS) aboard the James Webb Space Telescope, the research team observed WASP-121b for nearly 37 hours straight. This window covered more than one complete orbit, making it the most extensive continuous detection of helium ever recorded around a planet.

This prolonged observation allowed scientists to track atmospheric escape with unmatched detail and precision.

Two Massive Helium Tails Discovered

By measuring how helium absorbs infrared light, researchers found that gas around WASP-121b spreads far beyond the planet itself. The helium signal remains visible for more than half of the planet's orbit, marking the longest continuous observation of atmospheric escape to date.

Even more striking, the helium does not form a single stream. Instead, it splits into two distinct tails. One trails behind the planet, pushed away by stellar radiation and winds. The other curves ahead of the planet, likely drawn forward by the star's gravitational pull. Together, these gas flows stretch across a distance greater than 100 times the planet's diameter, or more than three times the distance between the planet and its star.

"We were incredibly surprised to see how long the helium escape lasted," explains Romain Allart, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Montreal, former doctoral student at the University of Geneva, and lead author of the paper. "This discovery reveals the complexity of the physical processes that sculpt exoplanetary atmospheres and their interaction with their stellar environment. We are only beginning to discover the true complexity of these worlds."

Modeling the Limits of Current Theories

The Department of Astronomy at the University of Geneva (UNIGE) has long been a leader in the study of atmospheric escape. Numerical models developed there played a key role in interpreting the first helium detections made by the JWST.

While these models successfully describe simple, comet-like gas tails, they struggle to recreate the double-tailed structure observed around WASP-121b. "This discovery indicates that the structure of these flows results from both gravity and stellar winds, making a new generation of 3D simulations essential for analyzing their physics," explains Yann Carteret, a doctoral student in the Department of Astronomy at the Faculty of Science of UNIGE and co-author of the study.

What Comes Next for Exoplanet Research

Helium has become one of the most effective tools for tracking atmospheric escape, and the JWST's sensitivity now allows scientists to detect it over unprecedented distances and time spans. Future observations will help determine whether the twin-tail structure seen around WASP-121b is rare or common among hot exoplanets.

Researchers will also need to refine their theoretical models to better explain how gravity, radiation, and stellar winds interact to shape these escaping atmospheres.

"Very often, new observations reveal the limitations of our numerical models and push us to explore new physical mechanisms to further our understanding of these distant worlds," concludes Vincent Bourrier, lecturer and researcher in the Department of Astronomy at the Faculty of Science of the University of Geneva and co-author of the study.

articles.personality_title: James Webb Space Telescope reveals exoplanet losing atmosphere with two giant helium tails
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study exoplanets, planets outside our solar system, to learn how they change over time. One way planets change is by losing their atmosphere, the layer of gases around them. Until now, observing this process in detail was difficult because it happens over time and was only seen briefly during certain moments.

**What happened** – Using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), astronomers watched the gas giant exoplanet WASP-121b for almost 37 hours, covering a full orbit around its star. WASP-121b is an ultra-hot Jupiter, a big planet very close to its star, making its atmosphere extremely hot and causing gases like helium to escape. The team discovered not one but two huge helium tails around the planet: one trailing behind like a comet’s tail and another stretching ahead toward the star.

**Impact** – This is the longest continuous observation of a planet losing its atmosphere and the first time scientists have seen such a double-tail structure. It shows that the process is more complex than previously thought, influenced by both the star’s gravity and stellar winds (streams of particles from the star). This helps scientists better understand how planets evolve and how their atmospheres interact with their stars.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to study more exoplanets to see if these twin helium tails are common or rare. They will also improve computer models to explain how gravity, radiation, and stellar winds work together to shape escaping atmospheres. This could lead to new discoveries about planet formation and behavior.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The James Webb Space Telescope’s detailed, continuous view of WASP-121b reveals new, complex ways that planets lose their atmospheres, advancing our understanding of distant worlds.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le télescope James Webb révèle une exoplanète perdant son atmosphère avec deux énormes queues d’hélium
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les exoplanètes, des planètes en dehors de notre système solaire, pour comprendre comment elles évoluent. Une façon dont elles changent est de perdre leur atmosphère, la couche de gaz qui les entoure. Jusqu’à présent, observer ce phénomène en détail était difficile car il se produit sur une longue période et était seulement vu brièvement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce au télescope spatial James Webb (JWST), des astronomes ont observé la géante gazeuse WASP-121b pendant presque 37 heures, couvrant une orbite complète autour de son étoile. WASP-121b est une Jupiter ultra-chaude, une grosse planète très proche de son étoile, ce qui chauffe beaucoup son atmosphère et fait s’échapper des gaz comme l’hélium. L’équipe a découvert non pas une, mais deux énormes queues d’hélium autour de la planète : une qui traîne derrière comme une queue de comète et une autre qui s’étire devant vers l’étoile.

**Impact** – C’est la plus longue observation continue d’une planète perdant son atmosphère et la première fois que des scientifiques voient une structure à deux queues. Cela montre que le phénomène est plus complexe que prévu, influencé à la fois par la gravité de l’étoile et par les vents stellaires (courants de particules venant de l’étoile). Cela aide à mieux comprendre l’évolution des planètes et l’interaction de leur atmosphère avec leur étoile.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les chercheurs vont étudier d’autres exoplanètes pour savoir si ces doubles queues d’hélium sont courantes ou rares. Ils amélioreront aussi les modèles informatiques pour expliquer comment la gravité, le rayonnement et les vents stellaires façonnent ces atmosphères qui s’échappent. Cela pourrait mener à de nouvelles découvertes sur la formation et le comportement des planètes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La vue détaillée et continue de WASP-121b par le télescope James Webb révèle des façons nouvelles et complexes dont les planètes perdent leur atmosphère, faisant progresser notre compréhension des mondes lointains.
articles.personality_title_es: El telescopio James Webb revela un exoplaneta perdiendo su atmósfera con dos enormes colas de helio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian exoplanetas, que son planetas fuera de nuestro sistema solar, para entender cómo cambian con el tiempo. Una forma en que cambian es perdiendo su atmósfera, la capa de gases que los rodea. Hasta ahora, observar este proceso en detalle era difícil porque ocurre poco a poco y solo se veía brevemente en ciertos momentos.

**Qué pasó** – Usando el telescopio espacial James Webb (JWST), los astrónomos observaron el exoplaneta gigante gaseoso WASP-121b durante casi 37 horas, cubriendo una órbita completa alrededor de su estrella. WASP-121b es un Júpiter ultra caliente, un planeta grande muy cerca de su estrella, lo que calienta mucho su atmósfera y hace que gases como el helio se escapen. El equipo descubrió no una, sino dos enormes colas de helio alrededor del planeta: una que sigue detrás como la cola de un cometa y otra que se extiende hacia adelante, hacia la estrella.

**Impacto** – Esta es la observación continua más larga de una atmósfera planetaria escapándose y la primera vez que se ve una estructura de doble cola. Esto muestra que el proceso es más complejo de lo que se pensaba, influenciado tanto por la gravedad de la estrella como por los vientos estelares (corrientes de partículas de la estrella). Esto ayuda a entender mejor cómo evolucionan los planetas y cómo sus atmósferas interactúan con sus estrellas.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean estudiar más exoplanetas para saber si estas colas dobles de helio son comunes o raras. También mejorarán sus modelos por computadora para explicar cómo la gravedad, la radiación y los vientos estelares trabajan juntos para formar estas atmósferas que se escapan. Esto podría llevar a nuevos descubrimientos sobre la formación y comportamiento de los planetas.

**Resumen en una frase** – La vista detallada y continua de WASP-121b por el telescopio James Webb revela nuevas y complejas formas en que los planetas pierden su atmósfera, mejorando nuestro entendimiento de mundos distantes.

articles.title: New NASA Artemis Payloads To Study Moon’s Terrain, Radiation, History
articles.summary: NASA announced Tuesday the selection of three new science investigations that will strengthen humanity’s understanding and exploration of the Moon. As part of the agency’s CLPS (Commercial Lunar Payload Services) initiative and Artemis campaign, American companies will deliver these research payloads to the lunar surface no earlier than 2028. “With CLPS, NASA has been taking […]
articles.content:
NASA

NASA announced Tuesday the selection of three new science investigations that will strengthen humanity’s understanding and exploration of the Moon. As part of the agency’s CLPS (Commercial Lunar Payload Services) initiative and Artemis campaign, American companies will deliver these research payloads to the lunar surface no earlier than 2028.

“With CLPS, NASA has been taking a new approach to lunar science, relying on U.S. industry innovation to travel to the surface of the Moon and enable scientific discovery,” said Joel Kearns, deputy associate administrator for exploration, Science Mission Directorate, NASA Headquarters in Washington. “These selections continue this pipeline of lunar exploration, through research that will not only expand our knowledge about the Moon’s history and environment, but also inform future human safety and navigation on the Moon and beyond.”

The selected scientific payloads are:

Emission Imager for Lunar Infrared Analysis in 3D (EMILIA-3D). The EMILIA-3D payload will create three-dimensional thermal models of the lunar terrain, using a thermal imager to measure the temperature of the landscape coupled with a stereo pair of visible-light cameras. These models will help the U.S. better image and navigate the Moon’s surface through improved understanding of the properties of the dusty lunar soil, called regolith, and what temperature measurements convey about the lunar surface. The principal investigator is Andrew Ryan at the University of Arizona.

Lunar Instrumentation for Subsurface Thermal Exploration with Rapidity (LISTER). The LISTER instrument will measure the heat flow of the Moon’s interior by drilling beneath the lunar surface, pausing at intervals to measure temperature changes and the ability of the subsurface material to conduct heat. A previous version of LISTER flew on the Blue Ghost Mission 1 CLPS delivery to the Moon’s near side, where it took eight temperature and thermal conductivity measurements and drilled down to about three feet beneath the lunar surface. This new LISTER investigation will study the heat flow generated by the Moon itself, giving us a better understanding of its thermal history. The principal investigator is Seiichi Nagihara at Texas Tech University.

The LISTER instrument will measure the heat flow of the Moon’s interior by drilling beneath the lunar surface, pausing at intervals to measure temperature changes and the ability of the subsurface material to conduct heat. A previous version of LISTER flew on the Blue Ghost Mission 1 CLPS delivery to the Moon’s near side, where it took eight temperature and thermal conductivity measurements and drilled down to about three feet beneath the lunar surface. This new LISTER investigation will study the heat flow generated by the Moon itself, giving us a better understanding of its thermal history. The principal investigator is Seiichi Nagihara at Texas Tech University. Site-agnostic Energetic Lunar Ion and Neutron Environment (SELINE). The SELINE payload will provide new insight into the Moon’s radiation environment by studying, for the first time at the lunar surface, the radiation from both primary galactic cosmic rays and their secondary particles and how this radiation interacts with the lunar regolith. Data from SELINE will improve our understanding of the planetary processes at work on the Moon, as well as inform space weather preparation and safety for long-term human exploration of the lunar surface. The principal investigator is Drew Turner at Johns Hopkins University.

These science experiments, selected through NASA’s Payloads and Research Investigations on the Surface of the Moon call for proposals, do not require a specific landing site on the lunar surface to gather their data, and NASA will assign them to specific CLPS delivery task orders at a later time.

NASA uses CLPS to send scientific instruments and technology demonstrations to advance capabilities for science, exploration, or commercial development of the Moon and beyond. By supporting a steady cadence of lunar deliveries, the agency will continue to enable a growing lunar economy while leveraging the entrepreneurial innovation of the commercial space industry.

To learn more about CLPS and Artemis, visit:

https://www.nasa.gov/clps

-end-

Alise Fisher

Headquarters, Washington

202-358-2546

alise.m.fisher@nasa.gov

articles.personality_title: NASA selects new lunar experiments to study Moon’s surface and radiation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is working on returning humans to the Moon through its Artemis program. To prepare for this, the agency uses the Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) initiative, which hires American companies to deliver scientific instruments to the Moon.

**What happened** – NASA has chosen three new science projects that will be sent to the Moon’s surface starting in 2028. These projects will study the Moon’s temperature, underground heat, and radiation. The experiments are called EMILIA-3D, LISTER, and SELINE. EMILIA-3D will create 3D temperature maps of the Moon’s surface. LISTER will drill below the surface to measure heat flow inside the Moon. SELINE will study radiation hitting the Moon and how it interacts with the soil.

**Impact** – These studies will give scientists better knowledge about the Moon’s environment and history. Understanding the temperature and heat flow helps us learn how the Moon formed and changed over time. Measuring radiation is important for protecting future astronauts from harmful space rays. Knowing more about the Moon’s surface will also help with safe navigation and building equipment for future missions.

**What’s next step** – NASA will decide later where exactly on the Moon these instruments will be placed. The selected experiments will be sent by private companies working with NASA under the CLPS program. The data they collect will help plan future human visits and long-term exploration missions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s new lunar experiments aim to deepen our understanding of the Moon’s surface, interior heat, and radiation to support safer and smarter space exploration.

articles.title: A faint signal from the Universe’s dark ages could reveal dark matter
articles.summary: After the Big Bang, the Universe entered a long, dark period before the first stars formed. During this era, hydrogen emitted a faint radio signal that still echoes today. New simulations show this signal could be slightly altered by dark matter, leaving behind a measurable fingerprint. Future radio telescopes on the Moon may be able to detect it and shed light on one of astronomy’s greatest mysteries.
articles.content:
The Universe began about 13.8 billion years ago with the Big Bang, a moment of extremely rapid expansion. Roughly 400,000 years later, after the cosmos cooled enough for atoms to form, it entered a long and quiet phase known as the "Dark Ages." This period lasted for around 0.1 billion years, ending only when the first stars and galaxies finally ignited and began producing light.

Although the Universe was dark during this time, it was not completely silent. Scientists believe hydrogen atoms emitted very faint radio waves with a wavelength of 21 cm. These signals are thought to preserve valuable information about the earliest stages of cosmic history.

Simulating the Early Universe and Dark Matter

Using advanced numerical simulations, researchers from the University of Tsukuba and The University of Tokyo explored how this 21-cm signal might behave under different theories of dark matter. Dark matter is an unseen form of matter that makes up about 80% of all matter in the Universe.

By recreating the structure and movement of gas and dark matter in the young Universe on powerful supercomputers, the research team was able to predict the strength of the radio emission during the Dark Ages with unprecedented accuracy.

What the Signal Could Reveal About Dark Matter

The simulations suggest that hydrogen gas during the Dark Ages produced a distinct signal with a brightness temperature of roughly 1 millikelvin (one-thousandth of a degree) when averaged across the sky. Importantly, dark matter is expected to cause variations in this signal of a similar size.

Measuring the overall radio signal across a wide frequency range of about 45 MHz could therefore provide critical information about dark matter, including the mass and speed of its particles.

Why Scientists Are Looking to the Moon

To detect such an extremely weak signal, astronomers need a location free from interference caused by Earth's atmosphere and human technology. Several upcoming lunar missions, including Japan's Tsukuyomi Project, aim to place radio telescopes on the Moon for this reason.

If these lunar instruments succeed in capturing the ancient radio signal, they could offer a powerful new way to investigate the nature of dark matter and deepen our understanding of how the Universe began.

Funding and Acknowledgments

H.P. was supported in part by grant NSF PHY-2309135 to the Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics (KITP). N.Y. acknowledges financial support from JSPS International Leading Research 23K20035. R.B. and N.Y. acknowledge JSPS Invitational Fellowship S24099.

articles.personality_title: Scientists simulate faint cosmic signal to study dark matter from the Universe’s early days
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – About 13.8 billion years ago, the Universe began with the Big Bang. After cooling down enough for atoms to form, it entered a long dark period called the "Dark Ages," before the first stars lit up the sky. During this time, hydrogen atoms gave off a very faint radio signal that still exists today.

**What happened** – Researchers from the University of Tsukuba and The University of Tokyo used powerful computer simulations to study how this faint 21-centimeter radio signal from hydrogen might have been affected by dark matter. Dark matter is a mysterious substance that makes up most of the Universe’s matter but cannot be seen. The team predicted how strong this signal should be and how dark matter might change it.

**Impact** – This work is important because the faint radio waves could carry clues about dark matter’s properties, like the size and speed of its particles. Detecting these changes could help scientists understand what dark matter is, which is one of the biggest mysteries in space science.

**What’s next step** – To find this faint signal, scientists plan to build radio telescopes on the Moon, where Earth’s noise won’t interfere. Projects like Japan’s Tsukuyomi mission aim to place these telescopes on the lunar surface to capture the ancient signals and test the new predictions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New computer simulations suggest that a faint radio signal from the Universe’s Dark Ages could reveal the hidden nature of dark matter, a discovery future Moon-based telescopes may confirm.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques simulent un faible signal cosmique pour étudier la matière noire des premiers jours de l’Univers
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 13,8 milliards d’années, l’Univers a commencé avec le Big Bang. Après s’être suffisamment refroidi pour former des atomes, il est entré dans une longue période sombre appelée « Âges sombres », avant que les premières étoiles n’illuminent le ciel. Pendant cette période, les atomes d’hydrogène ont émis un très faible signal radio qui existe encore aujourd’hui.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Tsukuba et de l’Université de Tokyo ont utilisé de puissantes simulations informatiques pour étudier comment ce faible signal radio de 21 centimètres provenant de l’hydrogène pourrait avoir été influencé par la matière noire. La matière noire est une substance mystérieuse qui compose la majeure partie de la matière de l’Univers mais qui ne peut pas être vue. L’équipe a prédit la force de ce signal et comment la matière noire pourrait le modifier.

**Impact** – Ce travail est important car ces faibles ondes radio pourraient contenir des indices sur les propriétés de la matière noire, comme la taille et la vitesse de ses particules. Détecter ces changements pourrait aider les scientifiques à comprendre ce qu’est la matière noire, l’un des plus grands mystères de l’espace.

**Étape suivante** – Pour trouver ce signal faible, les scientifiques prévoient de construire des radiotélescopes sur la Lune, où le bruit de la Terre ne gênera pas. Des projets comme la mission japonaise Tsukuyomi veulent placer ces télescopes sur la surface lunaire pour capter ces anciens signaux et tester ces nouvelles prédictions.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – De nouvelles simulations informatiques suggèrent qu’un faible signal radio des Âges sombres de l’Univers pourrait révéler la nature cachée de la matière noire, une découverte que les futurs télescopes lunaires pourraient confirmer.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos simulan una débil señal cósmica para estudiar la materia oscura de los primeros días del Universo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 13.800 millones de años, el Universo comenzó con el Big Bang. Después de enfriarse lo suficiente para formar átomos, entró en un largo período oscuro llamado las "Edades Oscuras", antes de que las primeras estrellas iluminaran el cielo. Durante este tiempo, los átomos de hidrógeno emitieron una señal de radio muy débil que aún existe hoy.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Tsukuba y la Universidad de Tokio usaron potentes simulaciones por computadora para estudiar cómo esta débil señal de radio de 21 centímetros del hidrógeno podría haber sido afectada por la materia oscura. La materia oscura es una sustancia misteriosa que forma la mayor parte de la materia del Universo pero que no se puede ver. El equipo predijo la fuerza de esta señal y cómo la materia oscura podría cambiarla.

**Impacto** – Este trabajo es importante porque estas ondas de radio débiles podrían contener pistas sobre las propiedades de la materia oscura, como el tamaño y la velocidad de sus partículas. Detectar estos cambios podría ayudar a los científicos a entender qué es la materia oscura, uno de los mayores misterios del espacio.

**Próximo paso** – Para encontrar esta señal débil, los científicos planean construir telescopios de radio en la Luna, donde el ruido de la Tierra no interferirá. Proyectos como la misión japonesa Tsukuyomi buscan colocar estos telescopios en la superficie lunar para captar estas señales antiguas y probar las nuevas predicciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevas simulaciones por computadora sugieren que una débil señal de radio de las Edades Oscuras del Universo podría revelar la naturaleza oculta de la materia oscura, un descubrimiento que futuros telescopios lunares podrían confirmar.

articles.title: Mars once had a vast sea the size of the Arctic Ocean
articles.summary: Spacecraft orbiting the Red Planet have helped researchers map out an ancient coastline that surrounded a large ocean billions of years ago
articles.content:
Spacecraft orbiting the Red Planet have helped researchers map out an ancient coastline that surrounded a large ocean billions of years ago

Mars was once much wetter NASA/USGS

Geological features on Mars suggest the planet once boasted rivers and broad coastlines around a vast ocean. The discovery provides the most direct evidence yet for the Red Planet’s former blue vistas.

“The presence of liquid water [on Mars] is a broad topic that includes rains, rivers, lakes, as well as oceans,” says Ezat Heydari, a geochemist at Jackson State University in Mississippi who wasn’t involved in the research. “In my opinion, this paper addresses the most important one: the ocean.”

A research team including planetary geologist Ignatius Indi and geoscientist Fritz Schlunegger, both at the University of Bern in Switzerland, made the discovery by analysing data gathered from different probes orbiting Mars, including NASA’s Mars Reconnaissance and the European Space Agency’s Mars Express and ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter. The ExoMars vessel is equipped with a specialised camera, the Bernese Mars, which can take high-resolution colour images. It was instrumental to the new work.

“These images allow us to distinguish subtle differences in surface materials that are invisible in black-and-white images,” says Indi. When combined with topographic data from the other probes, these tools become “geological time machines” that paint a clearer picture of how the Martian landscape formed, he says.

To apply the imagery to the question of putative past water sources on Mars, the researchers focused on Valles Marineris, a channel more than 4000 kilometres long that cuts along the Martian equator. They paid particular attention to a south-eastern region of the channel called Coprates Chasma. Its deep features are around 3.3 billion years old.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

By combining the new imagery with geomorphological analyses, the researchers identified many structures comparable to those that form on Earth where rivers pour into oceans or where alpine lakes materialise at the base of mountains.

“The Nile delta is a classic example,” says Schlunegger. If you removed the Mediterranean waters just beyond the terminus of the Nile, he says, you would see structures very similar to those detected on Mars.

Silty deposits left by ancient water on Mars Argadestya et al. 2026, CaSSIS

The new data also enabled the researchers to trace ancient coastlines around a former ocean, allowing them to measure its approximate size. They concluded that it was about as large as Earth’s Arctic Ocean. This would have been the largest ocean on Mars.

“Our research suggests that around 3 billion years ago, Mars may have hosted long-lasting bodies of surface water inside Valles Marineris, the largest canyon in the Solar System,” says Indi. “Even more exciting, these water bodies may have been connected to a much larger ocean that once covered parts of Mars’ northern lowlands.”

Previous research has given many scholars reason to believe Mars once held water, but this work has primarily been indirect. One study found Martian minerals that appear to have interacted with water in the distant past. Another found signs that ancient asteroid impacts triggered massive Martian tsunamis. While much evidence has hinted at a past humid world, definitive data is difficult to come by.

“The idea that Mars once had large oceans remains controversial – in part because, if they existed, their record is not fresh because they are so old,” says Michael Manga, a geoscientist at the University of California, Berkeley who wasn’t involved in the research.

The discovery has tantalising implications for the search for extraterrestrial life, but also offers a cautionary tale that Earth’s most indispensable resource might one day similarly disappear.

“The paper… addresses an issue that is in the mind of anyone who conducts research on the evolution of the planet Mars,” says Heydari. “Oceans on Mars would have acted just like oceans on Earth, and they are vital to the health of the planet.”

Journal reference: Paper: npj Space Exploration DOI: 10.1038/s44453-025-00015-8

articles.personality_title: Scientists map ancient coastline showing Mars once had a vast ocean
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long suspected that Mars, the Red Planet, had water in the past. Signs of rivers and lakes were found, but clear proof of a large ocean was missing.

**What happened** – A team of researchers used detailed images and data from spacecraft orbiting Mars, including NASA’s Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter and the European Space Agency’s Mars Express and ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter. They focused on a deep canyon called Valles Marineris and found land shapes similar to river mouths and coastlines on Earth. These features showed that about 3 billion years ago, a large ocean, as big as Earth’s Arctic Ocean, once covered parts of Mars.

**Impact** – This discovery is the strongest direct evidence that Mars had a massive ocean long ago. It helps scientists understand how Mars changed over time and gives clues about where life might have existed. Knowing Mars had oceans like Earth also shows how important water is to a planet’s health.

**What's next step** – Researchers will use this new information to guide future Mars missions. They may look for signs of ancient life in areas once covered by this ocean. The findings also encourage more detailed studies of Mars’ past climate and water systems.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New spacecraft data reveals that Mars once had a vast ocean, reshaping our understanding of the planet’s watery past and its potential for life.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques cartographient une ancienne côte prouvant que Mars avait un vaste océan
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques soupçonnaient depuis longtemps que Mars, la planète rouge, avait de l’eau dans le passé. Des signes de rivières et de lacs avaient été trouvés, mais la preuve claire d’un grand océan manquait.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une équipe de chercheurs a utilisé des images détaillées et des données de sondes spatiales en orbite autour de Mars, dont le Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter de la NASA et les missions Mars Express et ExoMars de l’Agence spatiale européenne. Ils se sont concentrés sur un profond canyon appelé Valles Marineris et ont trouvé des formes de terrain similaires aux embouchures de rivières et aux côtes sur Terre. Ces caractéristiques montrent qu’il y a environ 3 milliards d’années, un grand océan, aussi grand que l’océan Arctique sur Terre, couvrait une partie de Mars.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est la preuve la plus directe que Mars avait autrefois un océan massif. Elle aide les scientifiques à comprendre comment Mars a changé au fil du temps et donne des indices sur l’endroit où la vie aurait pu exister. Savoir que Mars avait des océans comme la Terre montre aussi l’importance de l’eau pour la santé d’une planète.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs utiliseront ces nouvelles informations pour orienter les futures missions sur Mars. Ils pourraient chercher des signes de vie ancienne dans les zones autrefois couvertes par cet océan. Ces résultats encouragent aussi des études plus détaillées sur le climat et les systèmes d’eau passés de Mars.

**Phrase clé** – De nouvelles données spatiales révèlent que Mars avait autrefois un vaste océan, changeant notre compréhension de son passé aqueux et de son potentiel pour la vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos mapean antigua costa que muestra que Marte tuvo un vasto océano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han sospechado durante mucho tiempo que Marte, el Planeta Rojo, tuvo agua en el pasado. Se encontraron señales de ríos y lagos, pero faltaba una prueba clara de un océano grande.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores usó imágenes detalladas y datos de naves espaciales en órbita alrededor de Marte, incluyendo el Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter de la NASA y las misiones Mars Express y ExoMars de la Agencia Espacial Europea. Se enfocaron en un cañón profundo llamado Valles Marineris y encontraron formas de tierra similares a desembocaduras de ríos y costas en la Tierra. Estas características mostraron que hace unos 3 mil millones de años, un gran océano, tan grande como el Océano Ártico de la Tierra, cubrió partes de Marte.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es la evidencia directa más fuerte de que Marte tuvo un océano enorme hace mucho tiempo. Ayuda a los científicos a entender cómo cambió Marte con el tiempo y da pistas sobre dónde pudo haber existido vida. Saber que Marte tenía océanos como la Tierra también muestra lo importante que es el agua para la salud de un planeta.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán esta nueva información para guiar futuras misiones a Marte. Podrían buscar señales de vida antigua en áreas que alguna vez estuvieron cubiertas por este océano. Los hallazgos también fomentan estudios más detallados sobre el clima y los sistemas de agua pasados de Marte.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Nuevos datos de naves espaciales revelan que Marte tuvo un vasto océano, cambiando nuestra comprensión del pasado acuoso del planeta y su potencial para la vida.
